results.title: Future eaters. Ep. 2: nomads of the wind
results.creator_credit: Richard Keefe, Ian Cuming, Television New Zealand. New Zealand Natural History Unit, North South Productions and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Episode two of a provocative three part ecological history of Australasia based on Dr Tim Flannery’s best selling book of the same name. It focuses on the exploitation for food of flora and fauna resources, firstly by the indigenous populations of Australia and New Zealand and then by European colonists. This episode looks at the impact of hunting and fishing by Maori before European colonisation. The primeval forests of New Zealand were home to many unique creatures which they devoured to extinction. They also rapidly depleted marine life until they no longer had enough to eat. The result was war over resources, followed by conservation measures to preserve food sources, some of which continue to this day. Written and presented by Dr Tim Flannery. Further information available at www.abc.net.au/science/future.

results.title: Future eaters. Ep. 1: taming the fire
results.creator_credit: Richard Keefe, Ian Cuming, Television New Zealand. New Zealand Natural History Unit, North South Productions and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Episode one of a provocative three part ecological history of Australasia based on Dr Tim Flannery’s best selling book of the same name. It focuses on the exploitation for food of flora and fauna resources, firstly by the indigenous populations of Australia and New Zealand and then by European colonists. This episode looks at the reasons behind the extinction of Australia’s megafauna, the giant marsupials that roamed the continent before human habitation. Presenter Dr Tim Flannery believes that they were wiped out by the Aborigines upon their arrival in Australia 40-60,000 years ago. The extinctions were the catalyst for environmental meltdown, from which the Aborigines made a triumphant recovery. Written and presented by Dr Tim Flannery. Further information available at www.abc.net.au/science/future.

results.title: Future
results.brief_description: Approaches the possibilities for life in the future through three distinct scenarios a world reached through technological developments, a world of economic, social and ecological collapse, and a world where the possibility of solving our problems and surviving becomes apparent

results.title: Furniture Craftsman
results.creator_credit: Edwin James Hipkiss and ERPI Classroom Films
results.brief_description: The work of designers and craftsmen in manufacturing “custom built” furniture. Pattern-making, laying out, band-sawing, power planing, joining, lathe turning, grooving, glueing, carving and finishing, as well as the relation between hand-tool operations and machine-tool operations are dealt with in detail.

results.title: Furnishing is fun
results.brief_description: How an average family in 1961, whose children have grown up, refurnishes the home. Shows the range of furnishings available in Australia, the advisory services, especially colour consultants and gives some indication of costs involved. Narrated by Gordon Bell and scripted by Burton Graham.

results.title: Furnace practice
results.creator_credit: George Wynn and CWS Film Unit
results.brief_description: A fuel economy film, for furnace men and plant managers, dealing with furnaces of all kinds - using coal, pitch, gas, oil or electricity. The ain is to get the heat and transmit it with the minimum loss. The chief subjects touched are firing methods, use of mechanical stokers; proper control of air supply; importance of cleanliness; repairs, maintenance, and improvements; recovery of hear from chimneys; need for careful records as a check on running economy.

results.title: Funny things happen down under
results.creator_credit: Joe McCormick, Roger Mirams and Pacific Films
results.brief_description: When the clubhouse of a group of country kids, known as the “Terrible ten” needs money for funding they invent numerous ways to make money. During their attempts at making puddings and selling mineral water they stumble on a formula for breeding coloured sheep.
